node.title: Moose Update and Test Error
node.bodyText:
I performed an update of moose using "mamba update --all"
I the performed the following:
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 6
I received the following error:
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/meshdivisions_Unity.C...
In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:19:
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C: In member function 'bool MooseServer::addParametersToList(wasp::DataArray&, const InputParameters&, const std::set<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char> >&, int, int, int, int, const string&)':
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:529:9: error: 'client_snippet_support' was not declared in this scope
  529 |     if (client_snippet_support && !default_value.empty())
      |         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:531:32: error: 'm_text_format_snippet' is not a member of 'wasp::lsp'
  531 |       text_format = wasp::lsp::m_text_format_snippet;
      |                                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:536:32: error: 'm_text_format_plaintext' is not a member of 'wasp::lsp'
  536 |       text_format = wasp::lsp::m_text_format_plaintext;
      |                                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:557:57: error: too many arguments to function 'bool wasp::lsp::buildCompletionObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, const string&, int, int, int, int, const string&, int, const string&, const string&, bool, bool)'
  557 |                                              text_format);
      |                                                         ^
In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseServer.h:13,
                 from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:53,
                 from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:12:
/home/twise/mambaforge3/envs/moose/wasp/include/wasplsp/LSP.h:604:6: note: declared here
  604 | bool buildCompletionObject( DataObject        & object          ,
      |      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:19:
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C: In member function 'bool MooseServer::addSubblocksToList(wasp::DataArray&, const string&, int, int, int, int, const string&, bool)':

/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:618:61: error: 'm_text_format_snippet' is not a member of 'wasp::lsp'
  618 |       int text_format = client_snippet_support ? wasp::lsp::m_text_format_snippet
      |                                                             ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:619:61: error: 'm_text_format_plaintext' is not a member of 'wasp::lsp'
  619 |                                                : wasp::lsp::m_text_format_plaintext;
      |                                                             ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C:654:59: error: too many arguments to function 'bool wasp::lsp::buildCompletionObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, const string&, int, int, int, int, const string&, int, const string&, const string&, bool, bool)'
  654 |                                                text_format);

In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseServer.h:13,
                 from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:53,
                 from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:12:
/home/twise/mambaforge3/envs/moose/wasp/include/wasplsp/LSP.h:604:6: note: declared here
  604 | bool buildCompletionObject( DataObject        & object          ,
      |      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:19:
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseServer.C: In member function 'bool MooseServer::addValuesToList(wasp::DataArray&, const InputParameters&, const std::set<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char> >&, const string&, const std::set<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char> >&, int, int, int, int)':

  818 |                                              text_format);

In file included from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseServer.h:13,

                 from /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.C:12:

  604 | bool buildCompletionObject( DataObject        & object          ,
      |      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/restart_Unity.C...
make: *** [/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:150: /home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/base_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1

Hello
Your version of WASP is too old. Use conda update moose-dev.
then check with conda list the versions of the packages.
If they are still old, you ll need to remove the moose conda environment and follow our instructions for installation again
Guillaume

After following all the given expected steps, The following appear to have been the solution
troubleshooting guide for Conda.

conda activate base
conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.03.05
conda activate moose
make -j 6 failed

cd moose
git checkout master
git clean -xfd
git fetch upstream
git pull
git submodule update --init
make -j 6 failed

The following actions resulted in make and test passing. Not sure if I could have just skipped to these actions
have resolved the issues without having done all the above.
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 6
cd ~/projects/moose/test
./run_tests -j 6

node.title: Parallel computing
node.bodyText:
I am having this error in my simulation run:
Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
Computing Initial Residual
  Computing Residual.                                                                [ 14.24 s] [ 2261 MB]
Finished Computing Initial Residual                                                  [ 14.24 s] [ 2261 MB]
Computing Residual.                                                                  [ 14.33 s] [ 2261 MB]

0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.028114e+03
Computing Jacobian....... ..double free or corruption (out)
Aborted (core dumped)
I have a machine with 24 cores and 96GB RAM however simulation is done with only 1 core. How do I tell MOOSE to run this simulation with more cores at same time.

Hello
You can do
mpirun -n 12 <your executable> -i <name of your input file>
I tried this, it's still displaying same error.

Ok can you compile in debug mode and run with the debug executable
Also can you watch the memory to make sure you're running out of memory? With top on Linux

I saw this message:
Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
Computing Initial Residual
  Computing Residual....................                                             [109.69 s] [14171 MB]
Finished Computing Initial Residual                                                  [109.69 s] [14171 MB]
Computing Residual.....................                                              [117.11 s] [14171 MB]

0 Nonlinear |R| = 5.157454e+02
Computing Jacobian........................................................................................free(): invalid next size (fast)
Aborted (core dumped)
===================================================================================
BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
EXIT CODE: 9
CLEANING UP REMAINING PROCESSES
YOU CAN IGNORE THE BELOW CLEANUP MESSAGES
YOUR APPLICATION TERMINATED WITH THE EXIT STRING: Segmentation fault (signal 11)
This typically refers to a problem with your application.
Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions
Then I saw this from the documentation: A "Segmentation fault," "Segfault," or "Signal 11" error denotes a memory bug (often array access out of bounds). What's this saying?

Looks like a genuine bug at this point.
Can you share your inputs and your mesh?
Or else could you please make a small case showing the problem

Attached below is the input file.
3D_cvf.i.zip
Thanks.

you are running out of memory
Code 9 for the exit code means something killed the process. This is pretty much always OOM.
Can you try with nx = ny = nz = 10 instead of 25 and see if you can get the calculation to finish

I hit an error in devel mode

Assertion `i < _size' failed
Access out of bounds in MooseArray (i: 8 size: 8)
at /Users/giudgl/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseArray.h, line 276
Stack frames: 14
0: 0   libmesh_devel.0.dylib               0x000000010c9ca2d0 libMesh::print_trace(std::__1::basic_ostream<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>>&) + 1044
1: 1   libporous_flow-devel.0.dylib        0x0000000102fc8570 MooseArray<double>::operator[](unsigned int) const + 688
2: 2   libporous_flow-devel.0.dylib        0x0000000103072358 PorousFlowTemperatureTempl<false>::computeQpProperties() + 52
3: 3   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x00000001046862b0 MaterialBase::initStatefulProperties(unsigned int) + 80
4: 4   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x00000001046dc948 MaterialPropertyStorage::initStatefulProps(unsigned int, std::__1::vector<std::__1::shared_ptr<MaterialBase>, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::shared_ptr<MaterialBase>>> const&, unsigned int, libMesh::Elem const&, unsigned int) + 168
5: 5   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x0000000104b18af0 ThreadedElementLoopBase<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*>>::operator()(libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> const&, bool) + 324
6: 6   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x0000000104ccc674 void libMesh::Threads::parallel_reduce<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*>, ComputeMaterialsObjectThread>(libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> const&, ComputeMaterialsObjectThread&) + 116
7: 7   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x0000000104ccc55c FEProblemBase::initElementStatefulProps(libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> const&, bool) + 84
8: 8   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x0000000104d032d4 FEProblemBase::initialSetup() + 15164
9: 9   libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x000000010461dde0 Transient::init() + 88
10: 10  libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x0000000105671f90 MooseApp::executeExecutioner() + 660
11: 11  libmoose-devel.0.dylib              0x000000010566a58c MooseApp::run() + 4584
12: 12  relap-7-devel                       0x0000000100ca7b64 main + 156
13: 13  dyld                                0x000000018a4d50e0 start + 2360
[0] /Users/giudgl/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseArray.h, line 276, compiled Mar  8 2024 at 16:16:16
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
So it might not be oom. I ll take a look probably tomorrow

ok I looked into this a little.
Porous flow materials aren't coded for second order variables.
You should make elem_type = HEX8 (or comment it out) then change the displacements to be first order.
If you want to use second order variables, you'll need to adapt quite a bit of logic in the porous flow materials, which I think is there for nodal lumping

node.title: Performance issues on HPC
node.bodyText:
Dear moose developpers,
I have installed moose on a National HPC. When Testing, I noticed that On my old Dell station moose run faster than on the HPC Cluster ! The cluster has the most new and performant nodes possible I could have. The engineers told me that moose was not compiled with good optimization options to profit from the cluster capabilities. Here my compilation (offline)  slurm script:
`module purge
source /opt/cray/pe/cpe/23.02/restore_lmod_system_defaults.sh
module load PrgEnv-gnu
module load craype-x86-genoa
module load cray-python
module load craype-network-ofi
module load CPE-23.02-gcc-12.2.0-CPU-softs
module load cray-hdf5/1.12.2.1
module list

 make -j 40`


to run a job I use this:
`
#!/bin/bash
#SBATCH --account=cin4054
#SBATCH --job-name=<miehe>
#SBATCH --constraint=GENOA
#SBATCH --nodes=1
#SBATCH --ntasks-per-node=20
#SBATCH --cpus-per-task=1
#SBATCH --threads-per-core=1
#SBATCH --ntasks=20
#SBATCH --time=23:59:00
module purge
source /opt/cray/pe/cpe/23.02/restore_lmod_system_defaults.sh
module load PrgEnv-gnu
module load craype-x86-genoa
module load cray-python
module load craype-network-ofi
module load CPE-23.02-gcc-12.2.0-CPU-softs
module load cray-hdf5/1.12.2.1
module list
export MOOSE_MPI_COMMAND="srun"
source ~/.bashrc                           
srun  -- combined-opt   -i CoupledTri_960.i  > CoupledTri_960

`
Thank you for any suggestion.
Regards,
Saber

Hello
Which installation path did you follow?
Was the MPI distribution used compiled by the cluster administrators?
Guillaume

I have followed this :
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/getting_started/installation/offline_installation.html
The cluster is 👍
https://dci.dci-gitlab.cines.fr/webextranet/user_support/index.html#connecting
and MPI are 👍
module available
---- /opt/cray/pe/lmod/modulefiles/comnet/crayclang/14.0/ofi/1.0 ----
cray-mpich/8.1.20 (L,D)    cray-mpich/8.1.21

Where:
 L:  Module is loaded
 D:  Default Module

ok I dont have any big ideas on this. You can pass additional flags to compile with higher optimization levels, for example -o3 (we default to o2) and -march=native if you want to try optimizing more.
@friedmud or @permcody may want to pitch in

The performance is so poor that it is far less that what I could obtain in an old Dell station !
Something is wrong I guess, since the cluster I want to use is the most "new" and "performant" of the country !

ok I dont have any big ideas on this. You can pass additional flags to compile with higher optimization levels, for example -o3 (we default to o2) and -march=native if you want to try optimizing more.



The performance is so poor that it is far less that what I could obtain in an old Dell station !
Something is wrong I guess, since the cluster I want to use is the most "new" and "performant" of the country !


Were there any differences? Can you provide a profiling report (your_app-opt -t) of both (one built with the optimizations @GiudGiud mentioned, and one without)?

I have tried the combined module (combined-opt) on my old Dell station and on the super cluster. And found that The old station is many times faster. I have compiled with the (default) options on both. This looks very strange to me.

I could not find in which script I should change the optimizer options, to specify o3 or -march=native.
regards,

The engineers told me that moose was not compiled with good optimization options to profit from the cluster capabilities

Did the engineers tell you what these optimization switches should be? I took some time to read up about the GENCI cluster. It looks like there might be different queues for different sort of work. One for AI specialized work (Instinct Accelerators (which probably wouldn't work well with MOOSE... I think!?), and another for general work (AMD EPYC 7003 series). Just stating this, in case we happen to be using a partition of this cluster where MOOSE is not suited to run on.
Usually, the following machine optimizations suffice:
-march=native
Here is a list I found containing a myriad of machine options for all known CPU types (you don't have to worry about these, but I found it interesting): https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Submodel-Options.html. Most likely this cluster falls in line with the x86 machine archetype. However, native might fail, if the compiler being used is older than the CPU archetype. If that is the case, you then have to choose one from the list I linked. But more importantly, the cluster engineers should have told you what switches to use.
Once you know what switches to use:
The compiler flags are gathered from environment variables (normally). So when you have all the appropriate modules loaded, you should see CXXFLAGS populated. Like on my Intel Mac workstation using the Conda compilers for example:
❯ conda activate moose
❯ echo $CXXFLAGS
-march=core2 -mtune=haswell -mssse3 -ftree-vectorize -fPIC -fPIE -fstack-protector-strong \
-O2 -pipe -stdlib=libc++ -fvisibility-inlines-hidden -fmessage-length=0 \
-isystem /Users/jason/conda3/envs/moose/include -std=c++17
As you can see, Conda sets-march=core2 which is optimized for the very old Intel Core2 archetype :) (off topic: Conda chooses to optimize with core2, so that the binaries they make available, operate on a wide number of CPUs).

@selarem
Can you comment on any of the above? It might be that the cluster engineers may know what optimizations MOOSE needs on their cluster. We should ask them: -march=what?? optimizations.

Can you confirm that MPI is working properly? MOOSE prints out how many processors it's using and prints some stats about the partitioning as well right in the header. Are you seeing sensible numbers in that section?

I thaink MPI is working properly:
"Parallelism:
Num Processors:          8
Num Threads:             2
"
regards,

How many elements? Can you please paste th whole header?
If for example the default partitioning is terrible, this will lower performance

Example of header :
"
Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:           git commit 04afdb8 on 2023-09-25
LibMesh Version:         ceff84386bdc83d87e9eb98ac3a9b745711e415a
PETSc Version:           3.19.3
SLEPc Version:           3.19.1
Current Time:            Wed Feb 21 10:46:40 2024
Executable Timestamp:    Wed Feb 21 10:43:08 2024
Parallelism:
Num Processors:          20
Num Threads:             1
Mesh:
Parallel Type:           replicated
Mesh Dimension:          2
Spatial Dimension:       2
Nodes:
Total:                 231601
Local:                 11746
Min/Max/Avg:           11337/11755/11580
Elems:
Total:                 460800
Local:                 23030
Min/Max/Avg:           22885/23257/23040
Num Subdomains:          1
Num Partitions:          20
Partitioner:             metis
Nonlinear System:
Num DOFs:                694803
Num Local DOFs:          35238
Variables:               { "disp_x" "disp_y" "c" }
Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"
Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"
Auxiliary System:
Num DOFs:                5768407
Num Local DOFs:          289492
Variables:               { "vel_x" "accel_x" "vel_y" "accel_y" } { "strain_yy" "stress_yy" "kinetic_energy"
} { "resid_x" "resid_y" "bounds_dummy" } { "stress_xx" "stress_xy" "Von_Mises_stress"
"total_strain_yy" "total_strain_xx" "total_strain_xy" }
Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" "MONOMIAL" "LAGRANGE" "MONOMIAL"
Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "CONSTANT" "FIRST" "CONSTANT"
Execution Information:
Executioner:             Transient
TimeStepper:             ConstantDT
TimeIntegrator:          ImplicitEuler
Solver Mode:             NEWTON
MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP
Currently Executing
Performing Initial Setup
Finished Performing Initial Setup                                                      [^[[33m  8.34 s^[[39m] [^[[33m  757 MB^[[39m]
Time Step 0, time = 0
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------------+
| time           | resid_x        | resid_y        | top_x          | top_y          | total_kinetic_energy |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |         0.000000e+00 |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------------+
Time Step 1, time = 3e-08, dt = 3e-08
"
While you're at it, can you also print the profile? Just add a -t to your arguments.

this all seems reasonable. 35k dofs per core is fine
what preconditioning are you using? If it s one that does not scale I could see the performance loss there

SMP
REGARDS

Le jeu. 22 févr. 2024, 15:39, Guillaume Giudicelli ***@***.***>
a écrit :
…
 this all seems reasonable. 10k dofs per core is a little under what we
 prescribe but it s not a hard rule.
 what preconditioning are you using? If it s one that does not scale I
 could see the performance loss there

 —
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#26585 (reply in thread)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFBUGDEMHIZGJOOCL3JJMRLYU5KB7AVCNFSM6AAAAABCAB6JKOVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43SRDJONRXK43TNFXW4Q3PNVWWK3TUHM4DKNJXG4ZTA>
 .
 You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>
what petsc options though?

petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  vinewtonrsls'
solve_type = NEWTON # PJFNK
I do not think this will change a lot the speed, I have been using all of the possibilities as per petsc documentation. For nonlinear stiff problems, we need to be patient.

so you have constraints on the domain? I see the vinewtonrsls. Are they from Bounds objects?
LU is not a preconditioning that scales well with larger problems. If you plot the cost of the solve at various number of dofs, you should see a nonlinear increase in the cost. If you are already high up in that nonlinear increase with 700k dofs, that can be the problem

Yes I am using Bounds.
Is there any preconditioner that scales better?

The preconditioning is problem dependent. A lot of the preconditioners scale well but they wont work for your problem.
What did you try before resorting to using a direct solve (LU)? Do you know what the other codes are using / what is the state of the art for your physics?

node.title: CSVReader Error
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am trying to run my code to read a CSV file to use it within an AuxKernels and also Materials block. I was using this code some time ago with the CSVReader and it was working correctly, but now it is giving the following error:
invalid float syntax for parameter: AuxKernels/add_material_in_the_ellipsoid/ry=Input_Params
My code is the following. First I am importing the CSV as:
[VectorPostprocessors]
[./Input_Params]
type = CSVReaderVectorPostprocessor
csv_file = Input_Params_mm.csv
#header = true
[../]
[]
And then I am trying to use it in the AuxKernels as:
[AuxKernels]
[./add_material_in_the_ellipsoid]
type = FunctionPathEllipsoidAux
variable = level_set_var
vector_ry = ry # Column in Excel
ry = Input_Params # Radius of ellipsoid in y (mm)
[../]
[]
Is there now a new way to call the different columns and values?
Thank you in advance!

Hello
Did you check the documentation page on the moose website for the functionEllipsoidAux?
That information, the new parameter names, would be there

I think the problem that I am having is that the CSV is not reading the data correctly, or that the method that I am using is not allowed anymore. The parameters names are correct I think, but I do not know how to select the correct column and value from the CSV file as before.

There's a parameter to select that.
A common issue with the CSV is if you opened it on a windows machine and the line endings got messed up
Oh solved! Thank you very much! :)

node.title: I attempted to modify a vectorpostprocessor  SideValueSampler
node.bodyText:
I attempted to modify a vectorpostprocessor  SideValueSampler and I am getting the following error during make -j6:
In file included from /home/twise/projects/crab/src/vectorpostprocessors/SideVectorPostProcessor.C:10,
from /home/twise/projects/crab/build/unity_src/vectorpostprocessors_Unity.C:3:
/home/twise/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/SideVectorPostprocessor.h:15:7: error: redefinition of 'class SideVectorPostprocessor'
15 | class SideVectorPostprocessor : public SideUserObject, public VectorPostprocessor
|       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from /home/twise/projects/crab/build/header_symlinks/SideValueSampler_crab.h:12,
from /home/twise/projects/crab/src/vectorpostprocessors/SideValueSampler_crab.C:10,
from /home/twise/projects/crab/build/unity_src/vectorpostprocessors_Unity.C:2:
/home/twise/projects/crab/build/header_symlinks/SideVectorPostprocessor.h:15:10: note: previous definition of 'class SideVectorPostprocessor'
15 |    class SideVectorPostprocessor : public SideUserObject, public VectorPostprocessor
|          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
What do I need to do to rename and reuse this VPP?

Hello
You want to inherit from SideVPP, not redefine it.
So do something like:
class SideDiffusiveFluxIntegralComponentsVPP : public SideVectorPostprocessor
...
Thank you sir.

this looks fine to me.
How the source implementation going?

node.title: The Quadrature of the sampler is a sampling method
node.bodyText: What is the method for selecting sampling points in Quadrature? Does Quadrature mean orthogonality or integration?

Hello
It depends on the context.
There s sampling in the stochastic tools for various purposes.
There s a quadrature for numerical integration in the finite element equations solve.
In that context we sample every point in the quadrature chosen at the order defined.
I imagine you're considering a quadrature in the stochastic tools context?
Guillaume
Yes, when I was using polynomial chaos for uncertainty quantification, the sampler chose Quadrature
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/samplers/QuadratureSampler.html

node.title: [executioners][Transient] - Forcing it to go to the next time step when it fails (Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH)
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
So I encounter this error a couple time, and then my simulation would cut down time and still stuck, just wondering if we can force produce the results at the end of this timestep and then force it to go to the next time step when it fails.
I checked https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Transient.html but didnt find it, maybe i miss it?
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.63 s] [133236 MB]
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
            porepressure_L1: 1.01635e+07
14 Nonlinear |R| = 1.016351e+07
    Computing Jacobian...............                                                    [ 84.31 s] [133236 MB]
      0 Linear |R| = 1.016351e+07
      1 Linear |R| = 2.513842e+06
      2 Linear |R| = 1.217593e+06

      7 Linear |R| = 1.318631e+04
      8 Linear |R| = 1.096617e+04
      9 Linear |R| = 9.838786e+03

    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.19 s] [133256 MB]

    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.23 s] [133256 MB]

    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 93.72 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.18 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.23 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.07 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.59 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.09 s] [133256 MB]
    Computing Residual.................                                                  [ 94.33 s] [133256 MB]
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 14
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
  Finished Solving                                                                       [4776.63 s] [132841 MB]

Thank you!
Traiwit

Does it run with the line search turned off?
Line_search=none in the executioner
Hi @GiudGiud no, I use Line_search=bt (followed an example from porousflow, and been using it for a while), I actually don't know how does it work, do you think Line_search=none is better?

Line searches guide the update step in the Newton method. When they work they are faster. They don't always work with their default parameters.
So you can either turn it off, or pass some petsc parameters to it to try to make it work.

node.title: Help in implementing staggered scheme
node.bodyText:
Can anyone help how to implement this staggered scheme in moose ?

I tried using multi-app but it gives divergence errors when i try to solve steady-state problems using Transient.
Any help would be appreciated.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tafmec.2022.103348
This is the link of the document from which screenshot is taken.
Regards,
Ayush

Hello
A multiapp is a good way to do this.
You ll want to use a transient multiapp if you want to perform relaxation to steady state transients.
The main way to debug this is to freeze one solve with Problem/solve=false and see if the solution for the other one is correct
Guillaume

node.title: Get the material property value at 1D boundary
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I would like to get the material property value at the 1D boundary and use this value in ADMaterial. What should I do? Must I use a postprocessor? Is there any other direct way (do not need to modify input file)?
Thanks!

Hello
If you used a postprocessor you would not be able to keep the derivatives with AD.
Is this material defined all over the domain or only at the boundary?
Guillaume
This material defined all over the domain.
Are you using distrivuted memory parallelism? (MPI)
Does MOOSE use MPI automatically? I do not use MPI.

When you are planning to run the simulation, will you use MPI?
I m asking because having derivatives with regards to values on the boundary when the boundary is on another MPI processs s domain is going to be complicated
Yes, I think I will use MPI in the future.

Ok the postprocessor route won't do AD but it will work fine with MPI.
So maybe you should try that first. Use a postprocessor to compute a single average for boundary material, and use that value everywhere in the domain
Thanks!

node.title: Consolidation and drainage process
node.bodyText:
Hi，
When I simulated the consolidation of soil in porous flow, the loading process was set as an undrained condition, and when the confining pressure was increased to the expected value, the pore pressure remained unchanged when the drainage was opened.  This is different from the expected gradual dissipation of pore pressure.Why?
However, when the surrounding pressure remains unchanged and the axial stress continues to increase, the pore pressure will quickly dissipate.
Thanks for your help.
@cpgr
